Award.AwardTitle: From Unimodular Sobolev Maps to Image Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Real-valued functions have been extensively studied and play an immense role in many branches of science. A typical example is the temperature considered as a function of a point varying on the surface of the earth. By contrast, the theory of maps with values into spheres has not yet been sufficiently developed. A typical example of such a map is the orientation of a compass needle as a function of a point varying on the surface of the earth. The orientation varies regularly except at the North Pole and the South Pole. Such points are called the singularities of the map. The reason why mathematicians work with Sobolev maps (rather than smooth maps) is precisely to allow maps with singularities. The simplest example consists of maps with values into the unit circle (a.k.a. unimodular maps). They occur naturally in many physical phenomena (e.g., liquid crystals, superconductors). It turns out these classes of maps have an amazingly rich structure from the point of view of analysis, geometry, and topology. This is one topic to be investigated in this project. The position of a point on the unit circle is determined by an angle (called the lifting of the original map). Any unimodular map admits plenty of liftings (since the angle is measured modulo two-pi). The project will study "optimal" liftings in the sense that they have least total variation. A lifting is usually discontinuous (even if the original map is smooth): every traveler crossing the International Date Line is aware of this discontinuity! The principal investigator proposes to classify all optimal liftings of a given unimodular map using only the geometry of its singular set. More precisely, he and his collaborators conjecture that there is a one-to-one correspondence between optimal liftings and minimal surfaces spanned by the singularities. They have been able to establish the conjecture in many two-dimensional cases. For example, if the map has precisely two singularities located at the North and South Poles, optimal liftings are classified by the meridians. Another important topic is the uniqueness of liftings. The problem reduces to the following question: Given a function taking only the values 0 and 1, what additional assumptions imply that the function is constant? The standard condition is that the function be continuous (but this excludes many important physical problems). The principal investigator has been able to derive the same conclusion for a much wider class of functions, but a general condition is still missing. A key ingredient is a new formula that provides a way of approximating total variation by nonlocal functionals involving no derivatives.

The principal investigator has recently learned that some of the tools that will be either improved or developed from scratch in the process of carrying out this project could be useful in image processing. The need for efficient image restoration methods has grown with the massive production of digital images often taken, or transmitted, in poor conditions (e.g., by UAVs). Likewise, to achieve the best possible diagnosis it is important that medical images be sharp, clear, and free of noise. The analysis of fine structures (e.g., micro-calcifications detected in mammograms) is one of the major challenges faced in medical image processing. Blurred and distorted images need to be restored and enhanced before one can extract reliable information. Over the past twenty years sophisticated mathematical techniques have been used in this field. The principal investigator has established contacts with leading experts who surmise that his and his collaborators' discoveries may lead to more efficient algorithms used effectively in concrete situations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OUTCOMES FOR AWARD ID: 1207793     

                                HAIM BREZIS

The outcomes cover three interrelated directions of research:

1)   Variational problems with roots in Image Processing. 

Restoring the quality of distorted images is a fundamental challenge in Image Processing.  This is often done by introducing a filter and a variational formulation, i.e., a minimization mechanism.  In practice many types of filters are used. The celebrated ROF-filter (ROF= Rudin-Osher-Fatemi) is a convex functional involving the total variation. Existence and uniqueness of minimizers is standard. Another type of filter which has become popular in recent years involves non- convex, non-local functionals and a small parameter delta. Up to now, there was no rigorous mathematical analysis for filters of this form. Even the existence of minimizers was lacking. With H.-M. Nguyen we established:  i) the existence of minimizers, and ii) the convergence of these minimizers as delta tends to 0 to the minimizers of the ROF-filter. This fact came as a surprise to the experts in Image Processing and has concrete implications. The proofs are intricate and our paper has already stimulated further research.

2)   Sobolev maps with values into the circle.

The theory of Sobolev spaces from a domain Omega to the real numbers is a classical part of Analysis. By contrast, the theory of Sobolev maps with values into the unit circle is still underdeveloped. A standard example is the orientation of a compass needle viewed as a function of a point varying on the surface of the earth. The orientation varies regularly except at the North Pole and the South Pole. Such points are called the singularities of the map. Mathematicians work with Sobolev maps (rather than smooth maps) precisely to allow maps with singularities. We have completed with P. Mironescu a research monograph containing “everything you always wanted to know” about such maps.  The project turned out to be much more challenging than expected and runs over 500p. The book includes an abundance of new results and a long list of open problems. These classes of maps turn out to have a rich structure from the point of view of Geometry and Topology. Each map admits a lifting (the position of a point on the circle is determined by an angle called the lifting of the original map). In fact, any map admits plenty of liftings because the angle is measured modulo 2π and this ambiguity is a source of difficulties (encountered e.g. in Section 3 below).

 

Here are a few highlights:

i) We discovered a remarkable bijective correspondence between liftings of a given map u and surfaces spanning the singular set of u. In this correspondence “optimal liftings” correspond to “minimal surfaces”.  We also proved that the least energy required to produce maps having prescribed topological singularities (a natural physical quantity) has a simple geometrical interpretation in terms of least area.  The proof of this fundamental formula relies on Optimal Transport.  While writing the monograph we revisited the celebrated Monge-Kantorovich theory and found an illuminating connection between the original Monge formulation and the less intuitive dual Kantorovich formulation.

ii) We obtained optimal regularity results (in the sense of fractional Sobolev spaces) for the liftings. This completes a program initiated with J. Bourgain (during the years 2000-2004).  

iii) Smooth maps need not be dense in circle-valued Sobolev spaces. (This is in sharp contrast with real-valued Sobolev spaces). We have now found the precise diving line between the cases where density holds and fails. When density fails we are able to compute the distance of a given map to the class of smooth maps.

iv) We have investigated the effect of the topology of Omega (think e.g. of a torus) on these spaces. The bottom line is remarkably simple: either the space is connected or its connected components correspond to the standard homotopy classes.

 

3)   Functions f with values into the integers: when are they constant?

The original motivation comes from the study of uniqueness of lifting for maps into the circle (see Section 2 above). The answer was known to be positive for a vast class of functions f:  f is continuous, f belongs to VMO (=vanishing mean oscillation), f belongs to some fractional Sobolev space.  It was natural to seek a “common roof” covering these diverse cases.  Together with my collaborators (L. Ambrosio, J. Bourgain, A. Figalli and P. Mironescu) we invented a new function space having that property. The proofs are arduous but have a strong geometric flavor and yield an original formula for computing the perimeter of a set.  This new space might be of interest well-beyond the scope of our original problem.

 

   Three students supported through this Grant have defended their PhD (H. Castro, T.Sznigir, H. Wang) and have obtained jobs.
